impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="15">documenting a clearer causal pathway</cite> in their theory of change to better link activities to long-term outcomes.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize financial efficiency and want their sadaqah to support a lean, community-based organization serving both local US and international humanitarian needs.
donor_motivations: Value a high percentage of funds (90%+) going directly to programs

Prefer organizations with low overhead and zero fundraising costs
Want to support underserved communities in the Bay Area and West Africa
giving_considerations: The organization is currently in a period of revenue contraction
Governance is managed by a very small board
Focus is on direct service and capacity building rather than advocacy
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking large-scale institutional charities with extensive board oversight or those specifically looking to fulfill zakat obligations.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects that the organization tracks outcome metrics and has a documented theory of change, but lacks independent third-party evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The foundation utilizes a capacity-building model to minimize costs for underserved populations, focusing on food security, education, and health infrastructure.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that high program spending actually translates into measurable improvements in the lives of beneficiaries.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a negative revenue trend and ambitious goals for food and housing distribution, the foundation has significant capacity to absorb new funding.

strengths.detail: The foundation directs <cite id="8">95.1% of its total expenses</cite> toward direct program services, significantly exceeding the <cite id="11">industry standard of 75%</cite>.
The organization maintains <cite id="12">7.1 months of working capital</cite>, providing a robust financial cushion for its operations.
Support Life Foundation holds a <cite id="7">Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite> and <cite id="13">meets all 20 BBB Standards for Charity Accountability</cite>.

strengths_deep_dive: Support Life Foundation demonstrates a high level of operational leaness, as evidenced by its <cite id="9">$0.00 fundraising efficiency</cite>, meaning virtually no donor funds are diverted to fundraising costs. This efficiency is paired with a <cite id="14">perfect score of 100 in Culture & Community</cite> from Charity Navigator. Their impact is further validated by a <cite id="15">documented theory of change</cite> and the tracking of specific outcome metrics, such as their goal to <cite id="16">distribute 5 million pounds of food</cite> and house 250 refugee families.
rich_narrative.summary: founded in 2017, Support Life Foundation is a community-based organization dedicated to social and economic justice through high-efficiency programming and essential resource distribution. The organization operates with a lean model, reporting <cite id="1">total revenue of $1,228,678</cite> in the 2023 fiscal year. Their mission focuses on <cite id="2">minimizing costs for underserved populations</cite> through a diverse array of initiatives ranging from local food security to international development. Domestically, they serve the <cite id="3">San Francisco Bay Area, including Alameda and Santa Clara counties</cite>, while their international reach extends to <cite id="4">Sierra Leone and Cameroon</cite>. Key initiatives include the <cite id="5">'You Are Not Alone' (YANA) program</cite>, Project Educate, and the establishment of the <cite id="6">Health Center Yaoundé</cite>. The foundation maintains a <cite id="7">Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>, reflecting a commitment to public disclosure. Financially, the organization is notable for its efficiency, directing <cite id="8">95.1% of its expenses toward programs</cite> and reporting a <cite id="9">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>. Despite this efficiency, the organization faces a <cite id="10">3-year revenue CAGR of -22.8%</cite>, suggesting a period of financial contraction or stabilization following earlier growth.
